column4: Shifting cultivation — repetition only for new generation (Lystad 1958: 34); But whole gu.[?] of hered. land.; Lystad (1958: 133) — sedentary; Ward (1956: 49) — cultivate a plot thru lifetime; seems logical because of property system — e.g. bequeathing)
Lystad (1958: 34) - axes; Bowdich (1873: 273) - nothing but hoe; Lystad (1958: 140) - cutlass
Descriptions indicate much regularity in structure
Lystad (1958: 100) says “cemetery” but no indication in Rattray (1927: Ch. 14) of permanent marking; Busia (1951: 19) - royal mausoleum
lined and covered channels [underlined] - no; pipes [underlined] - yes
??; illustration looks like beaten earth on stone
Lystad (1958: 34) - Road to Kumasi; Lystad (1958: 36) – roads are traditional Ashanti
Plaster mentioned; just a layer of white clay applied wet
(-); Temple the most elaborate Rattray saw in Ashanti

?; familial [underlined]; Rattray (1929:  4) – to family; But basically usufruct – in practice, hereditary thru kin line; Rattray (1929: 353) – if abandoned by stranger, reverts to chief; Rattray (1929: 337) – usufruct of family property.
? (+); Land [underlined] - No!; implied by statement (Rattray 1929: 111) that this could not be done with slaves
of the crop [underlined]; called leasehold. Runs independently
written will, through a formal executor [underlined] - not in aboriginal times
Clothing [underlined] - weavers who made clothing alone?; Prof’l weavers
Wild (1936: 78-79) doesn’t say when, but remembered by old people
the only discs found in Wild were with a constant price – 6d.
Functionally equivalent to pawning (Rattray 1929: 367 + implied throughout chapter e.g. p 371); Bowdich (1873: 208) – 33% rate
Bowdich (1873: 47) – the market place; Bowdich (1873: 249) – to the market place every night
?; Middlemen; Ward (1956: 48) – from necessities of slave trade but not strictly a contact influence
But Rattray (1929: 109) – not necessarily their only job
states [underlined]; Bowdich mission indicates precedent + Rattray (1923: 109-111) – state as opposed to kingdom
food and drink, payment in kind or money [underlined]
Artisans and laborers [underlined]; Slaves; Hambly (1937: 643) – artisans
in addition to or instead of regular taxes [underlined]; war expenses [underlined]; Lystad (1958: 109) – yes, but no regular taxes
all profits from trade went to chief
in the sense that all profits from trading went into treasury. Plus implied in statement, no tax on imports from North
weaving, armoring, goldsmithing, pottery, woodcarving, mines [underlined]
Taxation is only source of revenue mentioned
Rattray (1929: 109-111) – govt monopoly on trade; Rattray (1923: 304) inspector of weights and measures
See Rattray (1927: 81) – says dowry but refers to gift by man to bride’s family: goes under [trait] #224
goldsmiths, kings, chiefs wear gold ornametns
Lystad (1958: 38) – looks like post-contact; Dupuis (1824: 61) – some houses well constructed, most not
at least 8 or 10 [underlined] ?; if king had 3333….
Bowdich (1873: 1) – slaves worked for king in the mountains.; Dupuis (1824: XXXI) – slaves do fishing; Bowdich (1873: 273-274) – work plantations
they revert to then equal family gp.
+ permanent..; + (a) some power to collect...; + (b) the power to conscript...; + some centralized judicial authority; + the power to formulate…
stranger can be dispossessed from land (Rattray 1929: 352-353); Fortes (1950: 253) – legal priority of local allegiance
Heir apparent [underlined]; experience in provincial adminnistration impotant for political service
captain of messengers, captain for executions, captain for market, bands, burial grounds
(-); No mention; and population estimations vary so much before 20 c. among travelers who attempt estimates
?; there was a captain of messengers
Annals [underlined] - written? then no; but there was a historian who memorized history
land [underlined]; women [underlined]; grants of land to war chiefs
promulgates laws [underlined]; through messengers – never direct communication
Wives [underlined]; retainers [underlined]; killed [underlined]; tho not since British
Mausoleum; Rattray (1927: 117) – Brass coffer – not buried. Opened for ceremonies
(-); Ruler has no property. Harem lives outside village
?; Only mentioned in context of white men, but so common with missions that probably known beforehand
oath of service; recognition of obligation [underlined]
A private offence brought to lineage head
required [underlined] ? Is trad’ly done – looks prescribed; Rattray (1929: 381,383) – sworn evidence
compurgation [underlined] – by whom? No, if by defendant
?; If swears by lesser god, expected to lie; if by greater god, assumed truth (Rattray). But Bowdich (1873: 198-199) mentions penalty
with consent of people only, tho – Rattray (1929: 407)
Menstruating woman entering shrine is killed – Rattray. Cursing king = death
Most [underlined]? - Many, enuf to make a body of law. Private offences infinite in any soc.

Murder; Rattray (1929: 297) — true. But Rattray (1929: 311-312) — cursing King punishable on the spot: private? Many crimes have private punishments; by crimes offending gods are legally punishable; some crimes private many exist, as in any soc. – not enumerated. Define crime
thank-offering by innocent to chief; blood money to commute death sentence – functionally a fine; Fuller (1921: 21) – Atenye

property confiscated [underlined] - yes (Rattray 1929: 301); Fortes (1950: 265), Rattray (1929: 111,114) – a thank-offering by innocent; blood money as commutation of sentence; Rattray (1929: 378) – “not often”
other than a political leader [underlined]; general [underlined]
captains [underlined]; but have other duties + chosen ad hoc
Based on kinship service and other (Rattray 1929: 120-121); + semi-perm standing army. War is in preparation for several years (Rattray 1929: 125)
A kin obligation — land is taken away. the “rent” for land
Ashanti expansion took place by capturing new territory
(-); Not mentioned in description of army org.
Fuller (1921: 22) refers only to close by people
King is completely reducing another King to his authority
exclude, e.g., ancestral [underlined]; e.g. lake god
Rattray (1923: 100,134) – so ghosts would attend ghosts of dead rulers or upon fetish
(+); “Sacred persons” (Hambly 1937: 644); Stools most important objects – & these not not
Implied in Rattray (1927: 23) – okomfo are oracular
may have been – but probably [unreadable] made in Portugal
school [underlined]; training [unreadable] under tutelage of another priest
No mention; Rattray (1927: 300) comments on simplicity of design
Molded by hand with tools to shape e.g. wooden stick
(-) Lystad (1958) mentions mirror is British innovation
Hills [underlined] not settled, valley [unreadable]; no mention whether this British
(+); Ocean + sea fishing is by canoe
Rattray (1923: 219) – not written but highly structured & perfection demanded; Also drum language (Rattray 1923: 242 ff); Also – Rattray (1929: 117-118) – money noted by cowry shell
(-); uniquely designating each day of the year [underlined]-  No; Is not designated this way
Professional [underlined]; Heralds do this among other things
palm wine — fr[?] wild; rum + whiskey present
?; Removal of child from body by cutting
